dialogue_turns.speaker: Forge
dialogue_turns.text: A 3-D printing unicorn, Carbon, is about to get a massive $325 million injection.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A three-D printing unicorn, Carbon, is about to get a massive three hundred twenty five dollars million injection.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's the case even before accounting for the coming $300 million fundraise from 3-D printing unicorn Carbon, which was first reported by PitchBook on Thursday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Anvil
dialogue_turns.text: Oh right, that was just reported by PitchBook. And you know, it's part of this huge surge—like, so far this year, 3-D printing companies have already pulled in $410 million in venture funding.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh right, that was just reported by PitchBook. And you know, it's part of this huge surge-like, so far this year, three-D printing companies have already pulled in four hundred ten dollars million in venture funding.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So far this year, 3-D printing companies have attracted $400 million in venture funding, half the $800 million they had garnered in the entirety of last year, and surpassing the $300 million they'd attracted the year before that, according to the PitchBook analysis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Forge
dialogue_turns.text: Which is wild because that's already more than the whole of last year, um, which was $775 million total. And way more than the year before that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is wild because that's already more than the whole of last year, um, which was seven hundred seventy five dollars million total. And way more than the year before that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So far this year, 3-D printing companies have attracted $400 million in venture funding, half the $800 million they had garnered in the entirety of last year, and surpassing the $300 million they'd attracted the year before that, according to the PitchBook analysis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Anvil
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and if things keep going at this rate, we're talking about crossing a billion dollars for the first time in five years. That's a huge milestone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and if things keep going at this rate, we're talking about crossing a billion dollars for the first time in five years. That's a huge milestone.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If deal flow continued at that rate, it would cross the billion-dollar mark for the first time in five years, even before accounting for the Carbon deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Forge
dialogue_turns.text: And Carbon's deal alone would be the largest in the past five years—beating their own previous raise back in 2018.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Carbon's deal alone would be the largest in the past five years-beating their own previous raise back in twenty eighteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carbon's $300 million fundraise would be the largest deal of the past five years among 3-D printing companies, according to the PitchBook analysis, surpassing the same firm's earlier $200 million deal in February 2018.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Anvil
dialogue_turns.text: Right, they were valued at what, like $1.8 billion before this? And after this round, they could be worth as much as $2.6 billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, they were valued at what, like one point eight dollars billion before this? And after this round, they could be worth as much as two point six dollars billion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company is currently valued at $1.7 billion, and could be worth as much as $2.5 billion after the new funding.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Forge
dialogue_turns.text: It's not just them though—three of the top ten deals in the sector just happened this year. Desktop Metal raised $165 million, Markforged got $85 million…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's not just them though-three of the top ten deals in the sector just happened this year. Desktop Metal raised one hundred sixty five dollars million, Markforged got eighty five dollars million...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Three of the top 10 deals of the past five years have occurred in the first few months of this year, according to the PitchBook analysis: Metal 3-D printer maker Desktop Metal raised $160 million, reaching a valuation of $1.5 billion; Markforged, which makes 3-D printers for carbon and metal, raised $82 million, hitting a valuation of $820 million; and 3-D printing service provider Fast Radius brought in $48 million, reaching a valuation of $400 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Anvil
dialogue_turns.text: And Fast Radius brought in $50 million. The valuations are just skyrocketing across the board.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Fast Radius brought in fifty dollars million. The valuations are just skyrocketing across the board.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Three of the top 10 deals of the past five years have occurred in the first few months of this year, according to the PitchBook analysis: Metal 3-D printer maker Desktop Metal raised $160 million, reaching a valuation of $1.5 billion; Markforged, which makes 3-D printers for carbon and metal, raised $82 million, hitting a valuation of $820 million; and 3-D printing service provider Fast Radius brought in $48 million, reaching a valuation of $400 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Forge
dialogue_turns.text: You know, it's interesting—this isn't just niche hobbyist stuff anymore. Carbon's working with Adidas on those Futurecraft 4D running shoe midsoles.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You know, it's interesting-this isn't just niche hobbyist stuff anymore. Carbon's working with Adidas on those Futurecraft 4D running shoe midsoles.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carbon is best known for its partnership with Adidas, with whom it is partnering on midsoles for the German sportswear giants Futurecraft 4D running shoes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Anvil
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, it's industrial adoption. They've got big names backing them too—Sequoia, GV, Fidelity…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, it's industrial adoption. They've got big names backing them too-Sequoia, G V, Fidelity...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Redwood City, California-based company counts Sequoia, GV, Fidelity, General Electric and Adidas Ventures among its existing investors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Forge
dialogue_turns.text: Even though these numbers are still small compared to software or biotech, for 3-D printing, this is a massive acceleration.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even though these numbers are still small compared to software or biotech, for three-D printing, this is a massive acceleration.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While those dollars are a pittance compared to the funding numbers for healthcare or software companies, they represent a big bump up for 3-D printing, which has been gaining adoption in the industrial sector and has spawned hundreds of new startups.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Anvil
dialogue_turns.text: From like $95 million back in 2015 to potentially a billion this year? That's a serious turnaround.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: From like ninety five dollars million back in twenty fifteen to potentially a billion this year? That's a serious turnaround.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2014, for example, 3-D printing companies attracted just $100 million in VC funding, according to the PitchBook analysis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Forge
dialogue_turns.text: Makes you wonder what's next—like, mainstream manufacturing might really be shifting under our feet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Makes you wonder what's next-like, mainstream manufacturing might really be shifting under our feet.

artist_script:
Forge: A 3-D printing unicorn, Carbon, is about to get a massive $325 million injection.
Anvil: Oh right, that was just reported by PitchBook. And you know, it's part of this huge surge—like, so far this year, 3-D printing companies have already pulled in $410 million in venture funding.
Forge: Which is wild because that’s already more than the whole of last year, um, which was $775 million total. And way more than the year before that.
Anvil: Yeah, and if things keep going at this rate, we’re talking about crossing a billion dollars for the first time in five years. That’s a huge milestone.
Forge: And Carbon’s deal alone would be the largest in the past five years—beating their own previous raise back in 2018.
Anvil: Right, they were valued at what, like $1.8 billion before this? And after this round, they could be worth as much as $2.6 billion.
Forge: It’s not just them though—three of the top ten deals in the sector just happened this year. Desktop Metal raised $165 million, Markforged got $85 million…
Anvil: And Fast Radius brought in $50 million. The valuations are just skyrocketing across the board.
Forge: You know, it’s interesting—this isn’t just niche hobbyist stuff anymore. Carbon’s working with Adidas on those Futurecraft 4D running shoe midsoles.
Anvil: Exactly, it’s industrial adoption. They’ve got big names backing them too—Sequoia, GV, Fidelity…
Forge: Even though these numbers are still small compared to software or biotech, for 3-D printing, this is a massive acceleration.
Anvil: From like $95 million back in 2015 to potentially a billion this year? That’s a serious turnaround.
Forge: Makes you wonder what’s next—like, mainstream manufacturing might really be shifting under our feet.
